The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that are of great interest to evolutionary and medical sciences. Here, we compare the genomes of two distantly related myxozoans to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that the myxozoan degeneration was accompanied by a reduction in genome size and gene content. In addition, we identify candidate genes that are likely to be important for the development of the myxozoan body plan. Climate change will affect the global food system, but the magnitude of the changes is difficult to assess because of the complexity of the system and the lack of data. We use a statistical approach to quantify the impact of climate change on maize production in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that the variability of maize production will increase substantially, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase. These results highlight the importance of investments in breeding for heat tolerance, which will be critical to ensure food security in a warmer world. They also underscore the urgency of reducing greenhouse gas emissions to avoid the most severe impacts of climate change. This study is based on a statistical approach, which can be extended to other crops and countries. However, it does not account for the effects of other climate-related risks, such as drought or pests and diseases. Thus, the results should be interpreted with caution.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling vascular function, including blood pressure, inflammation, and blood flow. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to perform a variety of functions. To control each function, the endothelium is equipped with a network of specialized cells that are able to communicate with each other. This communication network is critical for the endothelium to integrate multiple lines of information and coordinate endothelial responses. Here, we show that the communication network between endothelial cells is highly efficient and effective. The network is small-world, which means that the network has both local and global efficiency. The network is also highly dynamic, with short path lengths and a high degree of synchronizability. These findings reveal that the endothelial network design is effective for local and global efficiency in the interaction of the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells in order to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. This knowledge is important for understanding the endothelium and its role in health and disease. It also has implications for developing new therapies to control vascular function.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are critical for understanding the spread of the disease and for developing effective public health responses. We describe the design and operation of the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance systems. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The COVIDcast API is a resource that we hope will be useful to researchers, policy makers, and the general public.

We show that this Threonine residue is essential for the allosteric coupling and for the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter on activation. Social dominance is a key aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality in the establishment of social hierarchies is poorly understood. These results also suggest that the brain energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens may be a promising target for the treatment of anxiety disorders. This is of particular relevance in light of the fact that the nucleus accumbens is a key brain region involved in the treatment of anxiety disorders with drugs of abuse. Our findings also have implications for the understanding of the role of anxiety in the development of depression.

The design of mechanical structures with programmable responses is of great importance for various applications. However, the current design approaches are limited by the restricted material properties and structural patterns. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize composite structures with multiple material phases. The structures are digitally designed to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme responses under large deformations. The synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and exhibit irregular material distributions and organic shapes. They are then assembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed approach can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. It can also be extended to other fields, such as architecture, engineering, and biology.

IGF2BP1 is downregulated in fetal erythroblasts and upregulated in adult erythroblasts. IGF2BP1 mediates posttranscriptional loss of the transcription factor BCL11A, which is essential for fetal hemoglobin expression. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be relevant to the timing of the transition from fetal to adult hemoglobin in other species as well. The results also suggest that IGF2BP1 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies. This study also demonstrates the utility of primary human tissues for the study of hemoglobinopathies. This is the first report of a role for IGF2BP1 in the regulation of hemoglobin expression in humans.

These findings suggest that ferroptosis-inducing agents may be useful in cancer therapy for patients with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutations. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This practice has been shown to suppress melatonin, phase-shift the circadian clock, and reduce sleep quality. However, the impact of these devices on the circadian clock and sleep in the morning has not been studied. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device suppresses melatonin and reduces sleep quality, and that this effect is greater than reading a printed book. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. They also suggest that the use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime should be discouraged.

CTLA-4 is a negative regulator of T cell activation, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice induced a spectrum of autoimmunity, which was not observed in congenital deficiency. This indicates that CTLA-4 is required for both central and peripheral tolerance.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this order remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Phylogenomic analyses of these datasets resolved controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. We propose that the evolution of plant cell wall-degrading enzymes (PCWDEs) may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of an arsenal of PCWDEs encoded in their genomes. These results suggest that beetle diversity may have resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding PCWDEs. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is 1,700 km in diameter and 1,300 km in height. It is the densest part of the Earth, with a density of 13.0–13.5 g/cm3. The inner core is thought to have formed when molten iron cooled below the melting point. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. Using a persistent embryo method and molecular dynamics simulations, we demonstrate that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process, with the first step being the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our study provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). Specifically, marijuana abusers show reduced decreases in striatal dopamine and in brain reactivity to methylphenidate. These findings suggest that chronic marijuana use is associated with decreased brain reactivity to DA stimulation, which might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is the most complex cognitive system we know of. How does the human brain process this system? We developed a methodology that systematically links brain and language processing models to the behavior of real people performing the same language task. We find that the most powerful models of language processing can explain nearly 100% of the variance in brain and behavior. These models are based on recurrent neural networks, which have been shown to outperform humans on the same language task. Our results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that the next step is to develop models of language production. This would allow us to study the neural and computational mechanisms of language in a way that has not been possible before.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is still unclear how to design stable DL models. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This implies a classification theory describing conditions under which stable NNs can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results provide a theoretical foundation for the use of DL in scientific computing. They also suggest that the stability of a model is a key factor in determining the computational complexity of a problem.

This paper discusses a classic experiment that has been cited as evidence for this phenomenon. It shows that the experiment’s design flaws were not only overlooked at the time but also, in hindsight, undermine the conclusion that people are unable to understand exponential growth. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis, which is the causative agent of this disease, and compared it with that of M. leprae. Entanglement and entropy are key concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also fundamental to thermodynamics, which is the study of the macroscopic properties of isolated systems. The interplay between these concepts is a central issue in quantum statistical mechanics. We show that the entanglement dynamics in a one-dimensional system is completely determined by the entanglement spectrum, which is the spectrum of the reduced density matrix of the system. This result is valid in the space–time scaling limit, which is the appropriate limit to study the evolution of the system. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. This is a major step forward in the understanding of the entanglement dynamics.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. Here, we describe a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. The brain is the most complex and expensive organ in the human body. It is also the most vulnerable to environmental and genetic changes. To understand the evolution of brain complexity, we need to know how many neurons were in the brain of the ancestor of our lineage and how many we have today. This study reconstructs the evolution of brain size in amniotes, from the earliest chordates to humans. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin filaments are the main structural elements of the cytoskeleton, and their disassembly is essential for many cellular processes. The actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family is the main regulator of actin filament disassembly. However, how it does so in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we monitor and quantify the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations by using single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques, coupled to microfluidics. We find that local curvature favors severing, while tension surprisingly has no effect on cofilin binding and weakly enhances severing. Remarkably, we observe that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon cofilin binding. We find that this ADF/cofilin-induced torque increases the severing rate constant 100-fold. A consequence of this mechanism is that cross-linked filament networks are severed by cofilin far more efficiently than nonconnected filaments. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many beverages and foods, is a major contributor to the rising epidemic of obesity in the United States. However, the effects of fructose on brain and behavior have not been systematically studied. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior. Our results also suggest that the effects of fructose on brain and behavior may be mediated, at least in part, by the hormone insulin. Our findings have implications for understanding the neurobiological basis of the obesity epidemic and for the development of strategies to reduce fructose consumption.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The recent admixture happened in a sex-biased way, with a faster settlement of Madagascar from Africa than from Asia. Finally, we found that the genetic structure is not only a consequence of the admixture but also of the settlement history. This suggests that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a short period of time.

We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a large-scale experiment, with more than 800,000 participants, and is the first to show that people can be influenced by the emotions of others in a social network. This work suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work also suggests that the emotional content of the social network may be a key determinant of the emotional climate of a society.

The presence of chemical modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) is common and has been shown to impact mRNA stability, translation, and translation efficiency. Here, we show that the presence of one of the most common modifications, pseudouridine (Ψ), can also impact the rate of protein synthesis. We find that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can impede the addition of amino acids to the growing peptide chain and the activation of the elongation factor, EF-Tu. We also find that the presence of Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence in the bacterial translation system. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in coding regions of mRNAs can have subtle effects on the rate of protein synthesis. This could have important implications for the regulation of protein synthesis in cells. (Show more)

We show that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more social engagement, and a healthier lifestyle. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a key feature of the evolution of vertebrates in general. We use a model of the energetic constraints imposed by the aquatic environment to show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a consequence of the aquatic environment rather than a release from it.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The reason for the preference of rhinovirus for the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity is not known. We show that mouse airway cells infected with rhinovirus exhibit a less efficient antiviral defense response at cool temperature. This results in higher levels of viral replication at cool temperature. Our findings have implications for understanding the evolution of rhinovirus temperature preference and for the development of rhinovirus vaccines.

The type IV pili (T4P) of Pseudomonas aeruginosa are a major surface adhesin and virulence factor. Here we show that T4P are also a mechanosensory system that detects contact with surfaces on short timescales. This mechanosensory system is required for the long-term attachment of P. aeruginosa to surfaces, which is a critical step in the pathogenesis of this pathogen. The mechanosensory system is also required for the production of a wide range of virulence factors, including the production of the biofilm matrix. These findings demonstrate that T4P are a mechanosensory system that detects contact with surfaces, and that T4P and the associated Chp system are required for the long-term attachment of P. aeruginosa to surfaces, which is a critical step in the pathogenesis of this pathogen. This system is thus a potential target for the development of new antibacterial strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades. However, the impact of pesticides on aquatic ecosystems is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global extent of pesticide contamination of surface waters. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This is a major step forward in our understanding of the impact of pesticides on the environment.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the world, and the animal world is no exception. While many species are susceptible to severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2 is not well understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, a common cervid in North America. We also show that the number of deer-to-deer transmissions increased during the winter months, when human cases were at their peak. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic. Our study highlights the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This will be critical to developing effective strategies for mitigating the spread of the virus. (Show more)

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins. The exact mechanisms underlying the development of these pathologies are not fully understood, but it is clear that the immune system plays a role in the pathogenesis of AD. Here, we show that neurons, which are the primary cell type affected in AD, are capable of producing a variety of immune factors, including cytokines and chemokines, in the absence of extracellular Aβ plaques and cell death. These factors are capable of inducing microglial activation and migration, and may be a significant contributor to the neuroinflammation observed in AD. Our findings suggest that the accumulation of Aβ in neurons may be a significant contributor to the development of AD.

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is today one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still missing. We present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which demonstrates that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Southern Levant in the fourth–second centuries B.C.E. We further show that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. The folding of a protein is a complex process that involves the formation of a series of intermediates. The intermediates are not the same for all proteins, but the intermediates are important for understanding the folding process. The intermediates are also important for understanding the role of mutations in the folding process.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, Np4 decapping is mediated by ApaH, which is inactivated by stress conditions that enable Np4 accumulation. Here, we show that, in the presence of disulfide stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is not known to decape Np4, becomes the predominant Np4 decapping enzyme. We show that RppH decaps Np4 by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to decape other RNAs, and we demonstrate that the unusual manner in which Np4 binds to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack. This positioning of the pyrophosphate bond is required for the deprotection of Np4-capped 5′ termini, which are then degraded rapidly. These findings have implications for the regulation of gene expression during disulfide stress. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, the underlying mechanisms are complex and not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a major amino acid, is a key molecule in the regulation of the immune system during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a metabolite of arginine, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression during sepsis. Our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This would be a major advance in the treatment of sepsis and other immune-mediated diseases. View Full-Text

The biomass of the biosphere is the main component of the total mass of the planet and is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. Here, we provide a global census of the biomass of the kingdoms of life, which is the first of its kind. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and that the biomass of humans is also an order of magnitude higher than that of all domesticated animals. We also show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all mammals combined. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. These results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They also highlight the importance of humans in the history of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature, such as earthquakes, avalanches, or forest fires, where the system is in a critical state and the system’s activity is self-regulated. SOC systems are characterized by the fact that the larger the activity, the faster the system returns to its critical state. SOC systems are also characterized by the fact that the probability distribution of the activity is a power law. In this paper, we study a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, sensors, and quantum technologies. However, its electronic properties are difficult to control, and its mechanical properties are sensitive to defects. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain, and that its electronic properties can be tuned by strain. We also show that diamond can be transformed into graphite, which is a stable phase. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. The role of plant-associated microorganisms in the evolution of plants is well established. However, the role of plant-derived antimicrobial peptides in the defense against plant pathogens is still poorly understood. Here, we report the antifungal activity of a unique structure and mode of action of a plant-derived antimicrobial peptide against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The mode of action of the peptide was revealed by structural and biochemical studies. The results provide a basis for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This is the first report of the antifungal activity of a plant-derived antimicrobial peptide against plant fungal pathogens.

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of sex differences. In this study, we use proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. Multiple seminal fluid proteins initially associate with sperm, but most become undetectable after sperm are stored. Female-derived proteins also begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Female-derived proteins that associate with sperm are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the platelet surface. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the effects of VWD mutations on bleeding. This suggests that the single molecule data are not artifacts of the bulk phase. The data also show that the on-rate is faster than previously thought. This is the first time that the effects of force on a protein have been shown to be relevant to the bulk phase. The data provide a mechanism for understanding the effects of force on VWF binding to platelets. They also provide a mechanism for understanding the effects of force on other proteins. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for human health. However, the role of viruses in this ecosystem is poorly understood. Here, we present a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which we use to identify previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. We find that the human virome is more complex than previously thought, and that viruses are associated with a wide range of diseases. This database will be useful for future research on the role of viruses in human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the interaction and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of the HSRL by conducting continuous observations of aerosols and clouds over Beijing. The observations show that the aerosol loading has no discernible effect on the liquid water path but increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface is important because it determines the extent to which life can exist on the surface. The temperature of the surface is also important because it is a key factor in the evolution of the surface. We show that the temperature of the surface has changed over geological time. This finding is important because it is consistent with both isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations of temperature change.

Ion channels are the main ion-conducting proteins in the cell membrane. They are also the main targets of drugs. Ion channels are open or closed, and the open probability is determined by the channel’s conformation. Ion channels have two types of gates, one for fast activation/deactivation and the other for slow inactivation/recovery. The activation gate of the K+ channel lacks a classic bundle-crossing structure and normally shows no C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that the K+ channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the K+ channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the K+ channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the relationship between activation/deactivation and inactivation/recovery in ion channels. The malaria parasite must overcome a number of physical barriers to successfully invade the red blood cell (RBC) host cell. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses a number of strategies to overcome these barriers, including the binding of its erythrocyte-binding antigen to the GPA receptor on the RBC surface. We show that this interaction leads to a change in the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process and suggests that the malaria parasite is not simply a mechanical system, but rather a system that is constantly adapting to the physical properties of the host cell. This would have implications for the development of new antimalarial drugs. (Show more)

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have implications for understanding the impact of climate change on influenza epidemiology and for the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza infection. The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how this process unfolds in the brain is unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s response to successive words in sentences varies with each merge, but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This pattern of activity was consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the language system that is shared by humans and other animals. Our findings may also have implications for the design of artificial language processors.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region in the control of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons, the dopamine system, and the locus coeruleus. This circuit may contribute to the development of obesity, a major health problem in the United States.

Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This technology could be used to improve the efficiency of nitrogen fixation in agriculture, which is a major contributor to global warming. The Amazon is losing forest at an alarming rate. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are used to incentivize community-based monitoring, but the effectiveness of these programs is unknown. We study a community monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was randomly assigned to 39 of 76 communities. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation in the communities, but the estimated effects are imprecise. The program may have reduced deforestation by increasing the visibility of deforestation and by providing community members with incentives to patrol forests. Our findings imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The auditory organs of animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. By sensing the motion of web threads, the spider remotely detects and localizes the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. The COVID-19 pandemic continues to have a devastating impact on the global population. The lack of affordable vaccines for low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) remains a major barrier to global containment. Here we report the design and characterization of a recombinant protein-based vaccine candidate that can be produced at large scale and is capable of inducing high-affinity antibodies that neutralize the variants of concern. This vaccine candidate may provide a cost-effective and scalable solution for the global vaccination of LMICs.

The ALK receptor is implicated in the development of several human cancers. In the zebrafish, the DrLtk gene is involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the neural crest. Here, we show that the zebrafish ALK homologs are involved in the development of iridophores. We also show that the ALK/Ltk family of receptors is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the involvement of the ALK/Ltk family of receptors in neural crest development. This knowledge will be useful for understanding the role of ALK/Ltk in human cancers. Furthermore, it will be useful for developing zebrafish models for human neural crest disorders. Finally, our results provide a framework for the development of small molecule ligands for the ALK/Ltk family of receptors.

The emergence of plague as a devastating disease in human history is a well-documented event, but the details of its early evolution are still largely unknown. We present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic to the Bronze Age, which provide a more complete picture of the pathogen’s evolution and ecology during this period. We show that the plague lineage that gave rise to the modern plague emerged from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor, and that the pathogen underwent a series of gene losses during its early evolution. We also show that the plague lineage spread across Eurasia, with a rapid expansion in the number of genomes recovered from the Bronze Age. These data provide insights into the early evolution of plague and its ecology during a period of rapid human population growth and migration. (Less)

Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management practices that can most effectively sequester SOC on grasslands remain unclear. We show that soil health management practices that reduce soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can increase SOC storage on grasslands. These practices also improve soil health, as indicated by increases in microbial biomass, microbial C-use efficiency, and the proportion of microbial biomass in POM. Our results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester SOC and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural systems. This framework can be used to identify the most effective management practices for SOC sequestration and to prioritize the development of management practices that can be implemented on grasslands worldwide. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a systematic approach to identify and prioritize the risk of zoonotic spillover of novel viruses. We developed a framework to identify risk factors for spillover and used this to systematically rank the potential for 887 wildlife viruses to spill over to humans. We validated the framework using data from a recent virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking system can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This will help to ensure that we are better prepared for the next pandemic.

Nectar is the main reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is an important trait that can attract pollinators and increase the probability of pollination. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work cumulatively identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also demonstrates how a previously undescribed compound can be derived from a previously undescribed enzyme. Our findings have important implications for understanding the evolution of nectar color in plants and vertebrate pollination. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period (5th–7th centuries AD) is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 480 and 650 AD. Our data indicate that the genetic ancestry of men generally closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. This heterogeneity includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, functional variants indicate that women also differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Examination of the panel of functional loci also revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. The ability to rapidly identify the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness is critical for the early deployment of public health response. We used a global cloud-based platform to perform unbiased metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) of RNA from 464 febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, dengue virus, Plasmodium knowlesi, and leptospirosis. Our findings highlight the importance of mNGS for the detection of undifferentiated febrile illness and the need for coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance. This approach can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study is a proof of concept for mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. The results also highlight the importance of the global cloud-based platform, CZID, for the rapid and unbiased analysis of mNGS data. This platform is a valuable resource for the global public health community. (Read more)

DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template during DNA replication. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, the replication of RNA is difficult to achieve, and the synthesis of functional RNA molecules is even more challenging. Here, we report the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and even tRNA. This ribozyme can replicate RNA, amplify short RNA templates, and, in low yield, even synthesize functional RNA molecules. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a step toward the in vitro evolution of life.

We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. In this study, we found that the treatment of tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can improve the clinical symptoms of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately. This study provides a new therapeutic strategy for the treatment of COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but its high toxicity to eukaryotic cells has led to the development of diverse mechanisms for its homeostasis. In this study, we demonstrate that the xan BGC of Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a copper-binding isocyanide analog. The copper-dependent antimicrobial properties of xan BGC-derived isocyanides suggest a role for these metabolites in the regulation of fungal interactions with competing microbes. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings provide insight into the evolution of metal homeostasis mechanisms in fungi and the potential for the development of antifungal agents targeting the copper micronutrient. The formation of silica polymorphs in a sedimentary environment is rare on Earth and on Mars. Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) SiO2 polymorph that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary environment on Mars is significant because it suggests that the sedimentary environment was a source region for silicic volcanism. The diagenesis of a high-SiO2 glass to opaline silica and the formation of crystalline magnetite and mixed-cation salts/oxides are also significant because they suggest that the sedimentary environment was a source region for aqueous fluids. The diagenesis of these products in a sedimentary environment is also significant because it suggests that the sedimentary environment was a source region for the formation of the sedimentary rocks in the region.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, which are the world’s most important carbon sinks. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not adapted to the new conditions. Our findings have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease is unclear. We found that Th17 cells were unable to induce colitis in a Th17 transfer model of colitis. Instead, Th17 cells were required for the development of colitis in recipients that expressed both Stat4 and the transcription factor IL12RB7. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of novel therapies for inflammatory bowel disease. (Read more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, but the mechanisms of disease progression are not fully understood. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. These cells can be used to study disease mechanisms and to test potential therapies. This method will enable the rapid production of large numbers of cells for high-throughput drug screening. This will lead to the development of new therapies for ALS. This study will also provide a platform for studying other neurodegenerative diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays an important role in the transmission of human pathogens. We now show that the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the gut microbiota and enhances the ability of Anaplasma to infect the vector. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the gut microbiota of their vector and may have implications for the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the evolution of birds. The short-tailed bird group is a major evolutionary lineage that is critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian bauplan. However, the currently limited known diversity of early branching short-tailed birds obscures our understanding of this major transition in avian evolution. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. This study also provides important information about the origin of the avian tail and the evolution of the mosaic evolution in early birds. (Read more)

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of these colors are used for camouflage. In this study, we show that the green color of anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history. We describe a new mechanism for the evolution of green coloration, which is based on the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin, the pigment that gives rise to the green color. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of green coloration in anurans and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. This study also demonstrates the power of the treefrog model system to study the evolution of green coloration. (Read more)

Hypoxia is a common feature of solid tumors, and is associated with increased proliferation, metastasis, and resistance to therapy. However, the mechanisms by which hypoxia promotes tumor growth are not fully understood. Here, we show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is increased in hypoxic cells, and ALKBH5 overexpression increases the percentage of breast cancer cells that are cancer stem cell-like. Thus, ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target in breast cancer. Our findings also suggest that ALKBH5 may be a useful biomarker for identifying breast cancer cells that are resistant to hypoxia. This may be important for the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. (Read more)

The parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was so thin that it was almost transparent. The source of this parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the animal origin of parchment in the future. (Show more

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The age model is refined by a detailed analysis of the carbon cycle and ecosystem recovery. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle volatility persisted for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. This will allow insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The age model will also be useful for the calibration of the geological timescale. This article is protected by copyright.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays a critical role in the regulation of various biological processes, including metabolism, cancer, and circadian rhythm. Here, we generate intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for vaccine development. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein in the presence and absence of the D614G mutation. We find that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike protein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent structural rearrangements required for membrane fusion. This may explain why the D614G mutation is so prevalent in the currently circulating viruses. Our findings may help to inform the design of future vaccines.

We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry and are of fundamental importance. We show that the chemical properties of atoms, electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward a better understanding of the chemical properties of atoms under pressure. It also provides a new perspective on the chemistry of the d-block elements.

Fire is a key ecosystem process, but its role in climate change is uncertain. We show that human ignitions and suppression can have a large effect on fire regimes, and that this can offset some of the warming caused by greenhouse gas emissions. We find that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks are most effective at slowing global warming under lower emission scenarios. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to understand and mitigate its effects in climate policy.

The gut microbiota of animals is a major contributor to host health and metabolism. In this study, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by a host to its symbiotic luminescent bacterium is a mechanism for the dynamic control of the host–symbiont relationship. The glycan is provided just before dusk, when the host is ready to migrate into the crypts to begin the night’s activity. The glycan is catabolized by the symbiont only at night, when the host is in the crypts, and the catabolized glycan is required for the host to maintain a healthy symbiont population. This study suggests that the provision of nutrients to the gut microbiota may be a general mechanism for the control of the host–microbiota relationship. (Read more)

Text data are ubiquitous and increasingly important for understanding social and political trends. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). The NVDRS summarizes violent death incidents with structured variables and unstructured narratives. We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. Motivated by known patterns in suicide and homicide by gender and recent research on gender biases in semantic space, we identify the gender bias of our topics (e.g., a topic about pain medication is feminine). We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We hope this method will be useful for researchers in many fields.

The Black Death, which occurred in the 14th century, is the most devastating epidemic in human history. It is generally assumed that the bacterium Yersinia pestis was introduced into Europe from Asia, where it had been circulating for centuries. However, this assumption is based on a single hypothesis, which has not been tested. We show that the introduction of Yersinia pestis into Europe was preceded by climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia. Our results provide evidence for repeated reintroductions of the bacterium into Europe, which occurred over a period of 40 y. This suggests that the Black Death was the consequence of a series of introductions of the bacterium into Europe, rather than a single introduction. This has important implications for our understanding of the epidemiology of the disease. (Less)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of coastal ecosystems. They are also a valuable resource for humans. In the Northeast Pacific, at least 20 species of asteroids are affected by a disease that has led to the mass mortality of thousands of individuals. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the mortality is associated with increased viral load. The findings have implications for the management of this important ecosystem.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, which allowed us to study the genetic history of Madagascar in a way that has not been possible before. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic contributions, with a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. The recent admixture happened in a sex-biased way, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The genetic structure is also influenced by geography, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide a comprehensive view of the genetic history of Madagascar. They also have implications for the settlement of the island and for the genetic diversity of the Malagasy people. They also have implications for the genetic diversity of the Malagasy people.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (denoted GlpD) and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA (denoted AzuR). The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation antibody drugs. (Show more)

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We also discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we propose a quantitative Crop Condition Index based on the CPC survey and demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed methodology can be used to improve the accuracy and reliability of crop monitoring systems in many countries. The CPC survey is the largest and most comprehensive crop monitoring system in the world.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is thought to be supported by a number of different mechanisms. Here we propose a new account of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that these changes can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is suitable for the binding of linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.
