The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important events in the evolution of life. It is also one of the most difficult to study, as it is marked by a gradual change in the environment and the lifestyle of the organism. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the rate of molecular evolution in plastid genomes is a sensitive indicator of the evolutionary state of the host organism. This may have important implications for the study of the origin of life and the evolution of the first cells. View Full-Text

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of cities to climate change. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of the 2015–2017 Cape Town drought by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 80% under high-emission scenarios by the year 2100. These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work emphasizes the need for urgent mitigation efforts to avoid more severe droughts in the future. (Abridged)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The discovery of a naturally occurring anthropogenic quasicrystal, the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal, provides a unique opportunity to study the conditions under which quasicrystals form and to understand the role of human intervention in the discovery of new quasicrystal-forming systems. The discovery of this material also provides a unique opportunity to study the history of the atomic bomb.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster proteins, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the O2-dependent enzyme. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also a common feature of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a model of MS. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1, which has been implicated in neuroinflammation. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a greater proinflammatory role in the later stage of EAE. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in astrocytes may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. Our study also provides a rationale for the use of a dual MAP3K inhibitor in EAE treatment. This study provides a comprehensive understanding of the roles of ASK1 in the development and maintenance of neuroinflammation in EAE. Our findings may also provide a rationale for the use of a dual MAP3K inhibitor in EAE treatment. This study also suggests that ASK1 in astrocytes may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the driest period in the state’s instrumental record and one of the most extreme droughts in the world. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to human activities. Our results suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the 2012–2014 drought.

Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial inheritance pattern. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This work is the first to our knowledge to demonstrate the pervasiveness of negativity biases in a large, cross-national sample of the public. It also offers the most comprehensive demonstration of individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results suggest that the tendency for news to be predominantly negative may be due in part to the fact that people are more likely to react negatively to news content than positively. The results also suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of store-operated Ca2+ entry, which is involved in a wide range of physiological processes. Mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and loss-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of ORAI1, which result in hematological abnormalities and a Stormorken-like syndrome. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spread of aggregates in a model of Huntington’s disease. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We also show that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in a neurodegenerative disease and suggest that the internalization of aggregates may be a therapeutic target. This approach could be used to study the spread of aggregates in other neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The immune system of bats is considered to be highly specialized and immunologically privileged, which is believed to be a key factor in the absence of viral diseases in bats. However, the immunosuppressant protein (MTX) in bats has been shown to be a potential virulence factor in viral infection. Here, we identified and characterized MTX, a potent immunosuppressant protein in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX inhibits the antiviral responses of the host and facilitates viral infection. MTX has no effect on the aminopeptidase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) and therefore does not impair the antiinflammatory function of LTA4H. MTX potently inhibits proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key regulator of the one-carbon unit pool, which is essential for cell growth. In mammals, SHMT1 is cytosolic and SHMT2 is mitochondrial. Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1/2 blocks HCT-116 colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2, and show that they block SHMT enzymatic activity in both the cytosol and mitochondria. We also show that formate, a one-carbon donor, rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). We show that this effect is rooted in defective glycine uptake in DLBCL cell lines, rendering them uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a rationale for targeting SHMT in cancer, and in particular, in DLBCL. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. The origin of the flowering plants is a major event in the history of life. The earliest flowering plants are poorly understood, and the origin of aquatic angiosperms is a major question. The study of Montsechia, a fossil plant from the Cretaceous, provides new insights into the origin of the flowering plants.

The human pathogen parvovirus B19 (B19V) is ubiquitous and has been associated with a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) from Eurasia and Greenland. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This acceleration is a strong indication that the climate system is responding to human-induced climate change. The rate of acceleration is consistent with the rate predicted by climate models, and the acceleration is large enough to make a significant contribution to sea level rise by the end of the century.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. The increase seen across birth cohorts cannot be explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity for the less educated, but fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The structure of the enzyme-catalyzed transition state is a key to understanding enzyme mechanism. However, the structure of the enzyme-substrate complex is also important, as it is the starting point for the next step in the reaction. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the enzyme-substrate complex in a key reaction of tryptophan synthase. This provides insight into the structure and dynamics of the enzyme active site and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This detailed picture of the enzyme-substrate complex is key to understanding why the natural substrate indole reacts, but an isostere benzimidazole does not.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe disease with a high case fatality rate. There is a need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a broad-spectrum antiviral that has shown efficacy against Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)-CoV in a mouse model. Here, we show that prophylactic and therapeutic remdesivir treatment in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection prevented and treated the disease, respectively. The data support the development of remdesivir for a clinical trial in MERS. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be a major advance in the treatment of these diseases. The availability of effective antiviral treatments would also help to reduce the risk of spillover of MERS-CoV and other zoonotic coronaviruses to humans. This would be a major public health benefit.

The gut microbiota of animals is a major contributor to host health and fitness. In this study, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by a host to its symbiotic luminescent bacterium is a mechanism for the dynamic control of the host–symbiont relationship. The glycan is provided just before dusk, when the host is ready to migrate into the crypts to begin the process of symbiont colonization. The glycan is then catabolized by the symbiont, which is thus provided with a specific nutrient at a specific time of day. This strategy allows the symbiont to maintain a stable population level, which is critical for the host to be able to see at night. This study suggests that the provision of glycans may be a general mechanism for the control of the activities of symbionts in the gut. (Read more)

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades, with disproportionate impact on students of color and students from low-income families. This study shows that a scalable, evidence-based intervention can reduce suspension rates. The intervention is simple: teachers are encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This intervention can be implemented in schools with minimal teacher training and has the potential to reduce racial disparities in suspension rates. It is scalable, low-cost, and evidence-based.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe pneumonia. To understand how MERS-CoV infects humans, we engineered MERS viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. These findings also suggest that the first cleavages may be significant determinants of other coronaviruses that cause severe pneumonia. Therefore, the first cleavages may be important targets for antiviral development.

It is therefore a critical target for cancer cells to remodel in order to evade the immune system and to grow and metastasize. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a widespread call for expanding vote-by-mail programs in the United States. However, the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes have not been systematically studied. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail programs are not likely to have a significant impact on the 2020 presidential election. Instead, the 2020 election will be decided by the policies and strategies of the candidates and the political parties.

The problem of selective inference is the challenge of assessing the strength of associations in a dataset that has been selected by the researcher. This is a problem that is becoming more important in the era of big data and complex statistical modeling. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The goal is to provide a framework for understanding and using these methods.

Endothelial cells (ECs) are the most abundant cell type in the blood vessel, and their dysfunction is a major cause of cardiovascular diseases. Therefore, the development of ECs is a promising approach for treating vascular disorders. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce ECs remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). In coordination with endogenous FOXC2 in fibroblasts, transduced ETV2 elicits expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and induces expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Consequently, ETVECs exhibits EC characteristics in vitro and forms mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for treating vascular disorders. Influenza A viruses are the most important pathogens of humans and animals. They cause annual epidemics and occasional pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which is an evolutionary advantage but complicates the packaging of the genome. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and nonspecifically decreases the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles. The interaction we identified involves regions not previously designated as packaging signals and is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides a molecular understanding of the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. It also suggests that the interaction we identified might be a target for antiviral therapy. Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen dramatically in recent decades, and climate change has been blamed for a portion of the increase. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with fetal abnormalities and neurological complications, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors, including global warming. Coral bleaching is the first step in the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis, which is the primary cause of the global decline of coral reefs. We show that the metabolic interactions between the coral host and its algal symbionts are a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of coral bleaching and may help to identify processes that could be targeted in the development of effective conservation strategies. This is of particular importance for the world’s coral reefs, which are among the most threatened ecosystems on the planet.

They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work provides insights into the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings may lead to the development of new strategies for cancer treatment and the design of more stable intestinal microbiomes. Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security and biodiversity conservation. We find that river fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our analysis also reveals that fishing pressure is most intense in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors, highlighting the need for improved management of inland fisheries. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. Our results highlight the importance of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein.

The ability to regenerate neurons is a key feature of development and a valuable property for the adult nervous system. However, the molecular mechanisms that control the transition from rapid growth to stable morphology in the adult are not well understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of genes that control the transition from growth to stability in the adult nervous system. It also suggests that the adult nervous system has the capacity to regenerate in a manner that is similar to development.

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genome integrity in eukaryotes. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions showing no detectable recombination. We also find that recombination is more likely to terminate in exons than in introns, suggesting that the process of gene conversion may be more active during transcription. These results provide a detailed view of recombination in a flowering plant, which will be useful for comparison with other organisms. They also suggest that the distribution of recombination in Mimulus may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms.

The resting brain is organized in functional networks, which are thought to reflect the underlying anatomy and physiology of the brain. Here, we show that the metabolic organization of the resting brain is also topographically organized, and that this organization is altered in disease. The metabolic organization of the resting brain can be used to identify disease-related changes in network organization. This approach can be used to identify the underlying anatomy and physiology of the brain, and to assess the impact of disease on this organization.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is required for efficient translation and is also involved in mRNA export and stability. Here we describe a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group, which is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We show that NAD-RNA is produced cotranscriptionally and is found on pre-mRNAs, but not on mature mRNAs. This suggests that NAD-RNA could modulate mRNA stability and translation. Our findings define a second 5′ modification in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that the NAD-cap could have a role in mRNA regulation.

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) showed that intensive glucose control in people with type 1 diabetes and their relatives can prevent the development of complications. However, the long-term effects of intensive therapy are not fully understood. We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation patterns at specific loci in blood cells of people with diabetes are altered during the DCCT and persist for several years during the follow-up of the DCCT Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. These epigenetic alterations are associated with glycemia and may explain the metabolic memory of intensive therapy. This study supports an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. These findings may also have implications for the treatment of other chronic diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high prevalence and a high social and economic impact. The etiology of the disease is complex and involves genetic and environmental factors. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence. View Full-Text

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is poorly understood, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit development and flavor is unknown. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce these compounds. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of nitrogenous volatiles and their role in tomato fruit development and flavor. This knowledge will be useful for improving the flavor of tomato fruit. (Read more)

Biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature, and that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning, and suggest that the additional impacts of warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have implications for our ability to predict the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning, and for the design of effective conservation strategies.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It is thought to encode a map of local space, but the organization of its neurons is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to encode local space, are strongly coupled among themselves but have weaker links to other cell types. These data suggest that grid cells might form a largely distinct network from those of other cell types. This could have important implications for the development of navigation algorithms. Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a number of genes and environmental cues. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not required for flowering of the host plant in a host–parasite interaction. Instead, FTs are able to move from host to parasite and interact with a dodder FD transcription factor to induce flowering of the parasite. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also shows that FTs can be used as a tool to synchronize flowering of different species. This may be useful for the development of new crop varieties with a synchronized flowering time. The results also provide a better understanding of the evolution of flowering in plants.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the substantia nigra are connected to the striatum in a manner that is distinct from the classical nigro–striato–nigral pathway. Instead, we describe a bouquet-like arrangement of striosomal fibers and dopamine-containing dendrites that are connected to the striatum and to other regions of the nigro–striato–nigral loop. These findings suggest that the bouquet-like arrangement of the dopamine-containing neurons may be a general feature of the dopamine system and may be important for the function of this system in health and disease. This arrangement may also be relevant to the recent finding that striosomes, which are a subpopulation of dopamine-containing neurons, are connected to cortical regions related to mood and motivation. Thus, the bouquet-like arrangement of the dopamine-containing neurons may be a key to understanding the function of the dopamine system in health and disease. This finding also has implications for understanding the effects of drugs that target the dopamine system.

We all have a sense of when we feel connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Finally, we demonstrate that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected: Conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. SAN cells are able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand by integrating information from the membrane and store clocks. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) and Orai1 channels, key components of store-operated Ca2+ entry, are selectively expressed in SAN cells. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores of SAN cells and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. Moreover, STIM1 influenced SAN function by regulating ionic fluxes in SAN cells, including activation of a store-operated Ca2+ current, a reduction in L-type Ca2+ current, and enhancing the activities of Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SAN cells that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well established. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by an increase in the level of jasmonic acid (JA), a key molecule in plant defense. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact to promote rice resistance against insect herbivores. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. These findings may have implications for the understanding of the role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in the regulation of macrophage function. They also suggest that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity may be a useful approach for the treatment of inflammatory diseases. This study also provides a platform for further investigation of the role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in the regulation of macrophage function.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is thought to be supported by a number of different mechanisms. Here we propose a unifying account of memory in language that is based on the adaptive properties of neurons. We show that the firing rate of neurons can be reduced by the activity of other neurons, and that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This work provides a computational neurobiology of language that is based on the adaptive properties of neurons. It also suggests a mechanism for the binding of linguistic features over time. This work is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant biotechnology. Here, we demonstrate the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery of siRNA to plants. We also show that the delivery of siRNA to plants is dependent on the endogenous gene silencing pathway. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a step toward the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for plant biotechnology.

Nutrient pollution is one of the most pervasive threats to aquatic ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient pollution comes from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large water bodies, leaving small tributaries largely unaddressed. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of coastal nutrient pollution, especially in large water bodies. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries in driving coastal eutrophication and suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to include these often-overlooked sources. Our study also demonstrates the value of a snapshot approach to understanding the spatial distribution of coastal nutrient inputs. This approach can be used to identify the most important sources of coastal pollution and prioritize future monitoring and management efforts. (Less)

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the rare combination of initial conditions is required to produce the observed universe. Our results suggest that the fine-tuning of the chemical network may be a necessary condition for the origin of the universe.

The mechanisms by which NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs change the intrinsic microcircuitry of the cortex, which in turn alters the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We then show that these changes are critical for the development of overt EEG paroxysms. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that the same key parameters that are altered by NMDAR-Abs may be susceptible to small fluctuations in the control condition, which could explain why some patients do not develop paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This may also explain why some patients respond to treatment by removing the antibody. Finally, our findings suggest that NMDAR-Abs may not be the only cause of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. Other antibodies, or even drugs, may also change cortical microcircuitry in a similar way. This may explain why some patients with paroxysmal EEG abnormalities do not respond to treatment with NMDAR-Abs. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, and the consequences of such a perturbation are of great interest. However, the history of abrupt warming events is poorly understood, and the extent to which they have occurred in Earth history is unknown. Here, we present a study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was accompanied by a global-scale perturbation of the carbon cycle, which is a key component of the Earth system.

The palm oil industry is a major driver of deforestation in Indonesia, a country with a high rate of forest loss. Certification is the primary tool used by companies and governments to reduce this loss, but the impact of certification on deforestation and fire remains unclear. We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in oil palm plantations, but that most plantations are too small to have a significant impact on deforestation. Certification also had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not yet a viable tool for reducing deforestation in Indonesia. (Show more)

The exocyst complex is a protein complex involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study not only provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation but also offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single genetic locus. In species with polygenic sex determination, multiple alleles interact to produce the sex of an individual. In some species, the sex of an individual can be decoupled from the sex of the gonads. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that the interaction of multiple alleles results in modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, including genital morphology, craniofacial morphology, gastrointestinal morphology, and behavior. These results suggest that polygenic sex determination can produce a diversity of secondary sexual characteristics, which may be important for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. This work also provides a case study of the effects of polygenic sex determination on secondary sexual characteristics.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by both vitamin A and iron. Iron is essential for energy and electron transfer, but also can be toxic. In this study, we show that iron levels in retinal pigment epithelial cells, a cell type that is also challenged by accumulation of vitamin A adducts, impact the oxidation and degradation of a bisretinoid, a chromophore that is a component of the photochemistry of the retina. These findings have implications for understanding the role of iron in retinal disease and for the development of therapeutic strategies. (Read more)

Siphonophores are a group of pelagic colonial cnidarians that use their tentacles to capture prey. They are considered a model system for studying the evolution of specialization in predators. However, the evolution of specialization in this group has been studied in a single dimension, focusing on the evolution of the morphology of the tentacles. Here we study the evolution of specialization in siphonophores in a broader context, by focusing on the evolution of the nematocysts, the specialized structures that are used to capture prey. We show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is linked to the evolution of the nematocysts, and that the evolution of specialization is not a dead end. Our findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The human hand is a complex and highly specialized structure. The evolution of the modern human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. The fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also provides a new fossil record for the early Middle Pleistocene of East Africa, a region that has been the focus of much recent research. (Read more)

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key regulator of the one-carbon unit pool, which is essential for cell growth. In mammals, SHMT1 is cytosolic and SHMT2 is mitochondrial. Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1/2 blocks HCT-116 colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2, and show that they block SHMT enzymatic activity in both cancer and noncancer cells. We also show that formate, the one-carbon donor, rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. We demonstrate that defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These studies identify a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited for cancer therapy. This work also provides a platform for the development of dual SHMT inhibitors. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change and is often cited as a threat to biodiversity and ecosystem services. However, the impacts of deforestation on people’s diets are less well understood. We show that deforestation can have negative impacts on people’s diets and that this is a neglected area of research. Our findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. Our study also highlights the importance of considering the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals. This is an important step forward in the field of nutrition geography.

Modern agriculture is a major driver of the global food production, but it comes at a cost of soil degradation. We show that the increase in farm machinery capacity has led to the propagation of subsoil compaction into deeper soil layers, with potential loss of soil ecological functioning. We also show that the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods. This suggests that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, calling for ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, that must have guided these prehistoric giants. Our findings have implications for the design of farm machinery and for the management of soil resources. They also suggest that the ecological strategies of sauropods may have been a key factor in the success of agriculture. View Full-Text
